column1: Jules Gabriel Verne is born in the port city of Nantes
column2: France
column3: the first of the five children who will be born to Pierre and Sophie Allotte Verne. His father
column4: an attorney
column5: will encourage young Jules to pursue a career in law. His mother
column6: from a ship-building family
column7: instills in him a love of the sea. 1831

column1: Victor Hugo’s Notre-Dame de Paris (The Hunchback of Notre Dame)  is published.1833
George Sand’s novel Lélia  is published by the well-known publisher Pierre-Jules Hetzel
column2: who later will publish Verne’s novels.1834

column1: Jules begins attending secondary school. During his years at school
column2: he excels in geology
column3: Latin
column4: and Greek. Also greatly interested in machinery
column5: he makes frequent visits to nearby factories. 1839

column1: It is said that the adventurous boy tries to run away to sea aboard a ship bound for the West Indies but is apprehended by his father before reaching open waters. 1843
Tahiti becomes a French protectorate. 1844
Alexandre Dumas’s Le Comte de Monte Cristo (The Count of Monte Cristo)  is published.1847
Jules begins studying law in Paris; he will receive his degree in two years. In Paris
column2: family friends introduce him to some of France’s most distinguished writers
column3: including Victor Hugo. Jules begins writing to supplement his meager allowance . Several of his plays are well received in theaters; his fiction appears in the Parisian magazine Musée des familles.

column1: Louis-Napoleon becomes emperor of France as Napoleon III. Novelists Alexandre Dumas (père and fils) secure Verne a position as secretary of the Theatre lyrique. 1853
French administrator Georges- Eugène Haussmann begins alterations and municipal improvements in Paris
column2: including the construction of the wide boulevards that distinguish the city to this day. The Crimean War begins
column3: pitting Russia against France
column4: England
column5: and the Ottoman Turks. 1854

column1: French poet Charles Baudelaire’s translation of the works of Edgar Allan Poe captivates Verne and initiates his lifelong admiration of the American author. 1857
Verne marries the widow Honorine de Viane Morel
column2: whom he had met the previous year. Quitting his position at the Théâtre lyrique
column3: he embarks on a career as a stockbroker at Eggly and Company
column4: although he continues to devote his mornings to writing. Charles Baudelaire’s volume of poems Les fleurs du mal (The Flowers of Evil) and Gustave Flaubert’s novel Madame Bovary  are published.1859

column1: Verne spends hours in the library gaining the scientific knowledge that will inform his fiction. He travels to England and Scotland. English naturalist Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection  is published. Work begins on the Suez Canal.1861
Verne travels to Norway and Denmark. His son and only child
column2: Michel
column3: is born. He meets the legendary photographer Nadar. 1862

column1: Verne’s manuscript Cinq semaines en ballon (Five Weeks in a Balloon) is accepted by Hetzel for publication. Until his death
column2: Verne will publish an average of two books a year with Hetzel
column3: forming the cumulative series known as Voyages Extraordinaires (Extraordinary Voyages). Hugo’s Les Misérables  appears.1863

column1: Five Weeks in a Balloon  is published to great success.1864
Voyage au centre de la Terre (Journey to the Center of the Earth) is published. Verne writes an article on Poe for Musée des familles.
De la Terre à la Lune (From the Earth to the Moon) appears. English writer Lewis Carroll’s Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland   is published.1866
Voyages et aventures du capitaine Hatteras (The Adventures of Captain Hatteras)  is published.1867
Verne travels with his brother Paul to New York aboard the 1868
Great Eastern. Les enfants du capitaine Grant (The Children of Captain Grant) is published. He purchases his first yacht
column2: the Saint-Michel
column3: named for his only son.1869

column1: Vingt mille lieues sous les mers (Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea) is published in two volumes (1869-1870). Its depiction of the submarine Nautilus  (named after the first submarine
column2: invented around 1800 by American engineer Robert Fulton) predates the construction of the first submarine by twenty-five years.1870

column1: The Franco-Prussian War breaks out; Verne serves in the Coast Guard. 1871
Une ville flottante (A Floating City )
column2: partly inspired by a trip to Niagara Falls
column3: New York
column4: is published. Verne’s father dies. The Franco-Prussian War ends.1872

column1: The Verne family moves to Amiens
column2: where Verne will reside the rest of his life. 1873

column1: Another Verne masterpiece
column2: Le tour du monde en quatre-vingts jours (Around the World in Eighty Days)
column3: is published. French poet Arthur Rimbaud’s confessional autobiography Une Sai- son en Enfer (A Season in Hell ) is published.1874

column1: Le Docteur Ox (Dr. Ox’s Experiment and Other Stories) appears
column2: along with L‘Île mystérieuse (The Mysterious Island). Around the World in Eighty Days is adapted for the stage. Verne purchases a new yacht
column3: the Saint-Michel II.

column1: Le Chancellor (The Chancellor)  is published.1876
Michel Strogoff  is published.1877
Les Indes noires (The Child of the Cavern) and Hector Servadac  are published. Verne buys his last yacht
column2: the Saint- Michel III.

column1: A leisurely cruise aboard the Saint-Michel III  takes Verne and his brother to North Africa
column2: Portugal
column3: and Gibraltar.1879

column1: Les Cinq cents millions de la Bégum (The Begum’s Fortune) and Les tribulations d’un Chinois en Chine (The Tribulations of a Chinaman in China)  are published.1880
Verne cruises to Scotland and Ireland. La Maison à vapeur (The Steam House)  is published.1881
Verne cruises to Holland
column2: Denmark
column3: and Germany. La Jangada (The Giant Raft)  is published.1882

column1: Verne moves his family to a larger house in Amiens with a circular tower; today it is a well-known Verne landmark and the headquarters of the Jules Verne Society in Amiens. 1883
Scottish writer Robert Louis Stevenson’s novel Treasure Island   is published. War in Indochina breaks out.1884
Verne voyages to Italy
column2: where Pope Leo XIII personally blesses his work. 1885

column1: Victor Hugo dies. English novelist Henry Rider Haggard publishes King Solomon’s Mines.
Verne’s deranged nephew
column2: Gaston
column3: shoots him in the leg
column4: laming him for life. This personal disaster
column5: and his growing cynicism about industrialization
column6: marks a turn toward pessimism in Verne’s outlook and writing. His longtime publisher
column8: dies. Verne sells the Saint-Michel III because of financial concerns. Robert Louis Stevenson publishes Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.

column1: Verne’s mother dies. 1888
Verne is elected to the municipal council of Amiens
column2: where he will serve for fifteen years. 1889

column1: Sans dessus dessous (Topsy-Turvy)  appears
column2: which contains notably negative views on the potential of technology. His later novels will take on various forms of social injustice
column3: from the plight of orphans to the corrupting power of missionaries in foreign lands.1895

column1: English novelist H. G. Wells’s The Time Machine  is published .1897
Le Sphinx des glaces (The Ice Sphinx)
column2: written as a sequel to Poe’s 1838 novel The Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym
column3: is published. Flagging health plagues Verne. His brother Paul dies. English writer Rudyard Kipling’s Captains Courageous and Edmond Rostand’s play Cyrano de Bergerac  are published .1899

column1: Verne’s Le testament d’un excentrique (The Will of an Eccentric )  deals with the oil industry’s ravages of the environment.1905
Leaving a drawer filled with manuscripts
column2: and with his family gathered at his bedside
column3: Jules Verne dies of complications    from diabetes. He is buried in Madeleine Cemetery in Amiens. His posthumously published novels
column4: altered considerably by his son
column5: Michel
column6: remain a source of scholarly debate and interest."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column1: ~ 20:00|"about eight in the evening"|"At about eight in the evening he signaled to stop. Hans sat down at once. The lamps were hung on a projection in the lava; we were in a sort of cavern where there was no lack of air. On the contrary. Certain breezes reached us. What caused them? That was a question I did not try to answer at the moment. Hunger and exhaustion made me incapable of reasoning. A descent of seven consecutive hours is not accomplished without considerable expenditure of strength. I was exhausted. The word ‘stop’ therefore gave me pleasure. Hans spread some provisions out on a block of lava
column2: and we ate with a good appetite. But one thing troubled me; our supply of water was half consumed. My uncle counted on a fresh supply from underground sources
column3: but so there had been none. I could not help drawing his attention to this issue."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column4: the instruments

column6: and a good quantity of fresh water gathered from the rocks were all put in their place."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column1: < 12:00|"Toward noon"|"Toward noon
column2: immense algae could be seen floating at the surface of the water. I was aware of the vital power of these plants
column3: which grow at a depth of over twelve thousand feet under the sea
column4: reproduce under a pressure of four hundred atmospheres
column5: and sometimes form barriers strong enough to impede the course of a ship; but there were never
column6: I think
column7: more gigantic algae than those in the Lidenbrock Sea."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column1: 12:00|noon|"At noon Hans fastens a hook to the end of a line. He baits it with a small piece of meat and throws it into the sea. For two hours he catches nothing. Are these waters uninhabited
column2: then? No. A pull on the line. Hans draws it in and lifts up a fish that struggles vigorously."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column1: 18:00|"six in the evening"|"I take the point and let the professor gnaw his lips with impatience. At six in the evening
column2: Hans asks for his wages
column3: and his three rix-dollars are counted out to him."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column1: ~ 12:00|"about noon"|"At about noon
column2: a very distant noise can be heard. I note the fact here without being able to provide an explanation. It is a continuous roar."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column1: 20:00|"eight in the evening"|"At eight in the evening
column2: we are less than two leagues away. Its blackish
column3: enormous
column4: mountainous body rests on the sea like an island. Is it imagination
column5: is it fear? Its length seems to exceed a thousand fathoms! What can be this cetacean that neither Cuvier nor Blumenbach anticipated? It lies motionless
column6: as if asleep; the sea seems unable to lift it
column7: and the waves play on its sides. The fountain of water propelled to a height of five hundred feet falls back down in a rain with deafening noise. And here we speed like madmen toward this powerful mass that a hundred whales would not nourish even for a day!"|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column1: 10:00|"ten in the morning"|"At ten in the morning the symptoms of a storm become more pronounced; it seems as if the wind lets up only to catch its breath; the cloud bank resembles a huge goatskin in which hurricanes are building up."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

12:00|noon|"At noon the violence of the storm doubles. We must safely stow every piece of cargo. Each of us ties himself down as well. The waves rise above our heads."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"
12:00|midday|"The shore had long disappeared behind the hills of bones. The rash professor
column2: unconcerned about losing his way
column3: took me along. We advanced in silence
column4: bathed in electric waves. Due to some phenomenon that I cannot explain
column5: and due to its by then complete diffusion
column6: the light illuminated all the sides of an object equally. Its source no longer resided at a particular point in space and cast no shadows. One could have believed that it was midday in the middle of the summer
column7: in the equatorial regions under the vertical rays of the sun. All steam had disappeared."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column1: ~ 18:00|"about six in the evening"|"The wind was not well-suited for a kind of vessel that was unable to maneuver against it. So in many places we were forced to push ahead with the iron-tipped sticks. Often the rocks
column2: lying just beneath the surface
column3: forced us to take rather long detours. At last
column4: after three hours’ sailing
column5: that is to say at about six in the evening
column6: we reached a place that was suitable for landing."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"By midnight our mining work was finished; the charge of guncotton was pushed into the hole
column2: and the long fuse ran along the tunnel and ended outside."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"At six we were up. The moment approached when we would blast a passage through the granite crust with the powder."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

~ 22:00|"about ten at night"|"I THINK IT MUST then have been about ten at night. The first of my senses which began to function again after this last bout was that of hearing. Almost immediately I heard
column2: and it was a genuine act of hearing
column3: I heard silence fall in the tunnel after the roars had filled my ears for long hours. At last these words of my uncle’s reached me like a murmur:"|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"

column1: 05:00|"five in the morning"|"I had regained some hope. But our last meal was over. It was at that time five in the morning."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"
~ 08:00|"about eight in the morning"|"At about eight in the morning
column2: another incident occurred for the first time. The upward movement stopped suddenly. The raft lay absolutely motionless."|"A Journey to the Center of the Earth"|"Jules Verne"
